Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 54039-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
November 2020 
 
 
 
People’s Republic of China: Strengthening Health 
Care Industry Development in Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The  knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  provide  evidence-based 
solutions for the development of the health care industry1 in the Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei (BTH) 
region of the People’s Republic of China (PRC).2 The TA will (i) provide a framework for improved 
coordination of health care industry policies and regulations, and (ii) disseminate research results 
and international comparisons of health care development to policy makers.  
 
2.  The TA is aligned with Strategy 2030 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and supports 
operational priorities 1 (poverty), 3 (climate change), and 6 (strengthening governance and 
institutional capacity) along with their corresponding operational plans.3 The TA is in line with the 
Government of the PRC’s Healthy China Action Plan 2030, which advocates strengthening the 
health care industry in the PRC to meet its future health challenges.4 The TA is included in the 
list of projects agreed upon between ADB and the Government of the PRC on 22 January 2020.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Although the PRC’s health care industry is one of the world’s largest, most pharmaceutical 
sales are domestic with 80% of the market focused on low cost generic drugs and 20% focused  
on complex and patented drugs, which are mostly imported and more expensive.6 The drugs are 
mostly purchased domestically by public hospitals and pharmacies, which account for a significant 
proportion of the PRC’s state health budget. The PRC is also a major global producer of active 
pharmaceutical ingredients required to develop more complex finished pharmaceutical products. 
However, the exportation of complex and innovative pharmaceutical products to international 
markets is less significant. About 97% of drugs sold by local Chinese manufacturers are generic. 
Despite its well-developed domestic pharmaceutical manufacturing sector, the PRC is a major 
importer of internationally developed pharmaceutical products. Since the imported products are 
covered under patent protection and are more expensive, the PRC spends a substantial part of 
its budget for medicine on imported drugs, driving up health care costs. The PRC lacks the 
development of innovative and high-quality blockbuster drugs and vaccines that can cater to the 
needs of the domestic market and be exported in the region and globally.7  
 
4.  The PRC’s pharmaceutical industry has been rapidly expanding since the 1990s. Its share 
of pharmaceutical industry output increased from 2.5% in 1995 to 18.3% in 2010 partly because 
of conducive national policies, economic growth, globalization, and domestic needs (including the 
 
1  The health care industry includes the pharmaceutical manufacturing industry, as well as the traditional Chinese 
medicine industry, health care equipment, and service industries. 
2  The Beijing Municipality (Beijing), Tianjin Municipality (Tianjin), and the Hebei Province (Hebei) make up the 
economically important BTH region in the northern part of the PRC.  
3  ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 1: Addressing Remaining Poverty and Reducing Inequalities, 
2019–2024. Manila; ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 3: Tackling Climate Change, Building 
Climate and Disaster Resilience, and Enhancing Environmental Sustainability, 2019–2024. Manila; and ADB. 2019. 
Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 6: Strengthening Governance and Institutional Capacity, 2019–2024. 
Manila.  
4  Government of the PRC. 2019. Healthy China Action Plan (2019–2030): Campaign to Prevent Disease and Promote 
Health. Beijing. 
5  The original title was Coordinated Development Strategies of the Health Care Industry in Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei. It 
was modified to better reflect the scope of the TA. The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of 
ADB’s website on 5 November 2020. 
6  World Health Organization. 2017. China Policies to Promote Local Production of Pharmaceutical Products and 
Protect Public Health. Geneva. 
7  Blockbuster drugs are extremely popular drugs that generate annual sales of at least $1 billion for the seller.

2 
aging population).8 The PRC is rapidly increasing investments in research and development, 
patents,  and  scientific  publications.  However,  despite  these  substantial  investments,  the 
innovation capacity of the PRC health care industry remains weak, with only a few successful 
pharmaceutical products recognized globally. For example, the PRC has only 18 drugs included 
in the World Health Organization’s list of prequalified drugs, compared with 355 from India––a 
comparable pharmaceutical manufacturing country in terms of size of industry. There are several 
reasons why the health care industry remains weak: (i) government policies and regulations favor 
the manufacturing of generic drugs for the local market over innovative drugs with export potential, 
(ii) new drug registration and procedures are cumbersome and lengthy, and (iii) concerns linger 
over the safety of pharmaceutical products despite initiatives to strengthen drug regulation 
enforcement.  Inefficiencies  in  drug  and  health  care  equipment  distribution,  poor  industrial 
planning, and disjointed regulations also drive up health care costs. 
 
5.  There  will  be  a  substantially  growing  need  for  better  access  to  high-quality 
pharmaceuticals and health care products in the PRC because of increasing demands. The key 
drivers of the increasing demand include the PRC’s rapidly aging population, the rising levels of 
noncommunicable lifestyle diseases (such as heart disease, diabetes, cancer, and hypertension), 
and the increasing purchasing power of the population desiring better health care and health 
outcomes. The PRC health care industry will benefit from a holistic and comprehensive policy 
framework that promotes innovation and the discovery of new drugs under favorable regulatory, 
market, financing, and technology transfer environments. Greater availability and access to high-
quality and cost-effective pharmaceutical and health care products can help achieve the goals of 
the country’s healthy action plan (footnote 4), which makes health the foundation of economic 
and social development, and prioritize health care industry innovation and scientific development. 
Strengthening the  health  care  industry  will  provide  multiple  benefits  in  the  PRC,  including 
contributing to the achievement of universal health coverage.9 
 
6.  The BTH region is one of the PRC’s most important industrialized regions and is a key 
pharmaceutical manufacturing hub housing domestic and international pharmaceutical firms. The 
government’s BTH integration plan benefits the region (known locally as Jing-Jin-Ji) by promoting 
improved models of development and integration in a densely populated and industrialized 
region.10 Although the health care industry makes up a significant portion of the BTH region, 
several challenges remain including (i) low levels of innovation, (ii) lack of coordination between 
policy-making initiatives and implementation, (iii) disjointed industrial agglomeration imbalances 
because of rapid development and industrialization of the region, and (iv) inadequate industrial 
support  factors  and  insufficient  service  platforms  for  health  care  industry  development. 
Coordination between Beijing, Tianjin, and Hebei can help improve pharmaceutical manufacturing, 
promote the development of innovative drugs, reduce inefficiencies and outdated practices, and 
share lessons learned.  
 
7.  The TA focuses on developing evidence-based strategies and policies to strengthen the 
health  care  industry  in  the  BTH  region.  It  will  address  the  lack  of  coordination,  industrial 
agglomeration, underdeveloped supply chains, and innovation in the health care industry by  
(i) assessing the industry policies, guidelines, and regulations; (ii) strengthening the health care 
 
8  J. Ni et al. 2017. Obstacles and Opportunities in Chinese Pharmaceutical Innovation. Globalization and Health. 13 
(21). p. 1. 
9  The universal health coverage requires all people to have access to the health services they need, when and where 
they  need  them,  without  financial  hardship.  It  includes  the  full  range  of  essential health services, 
from health promotion  to prevention,  treatment,  rehabilitation, and palliative care.  World  Health  Organization. 
Universal Health Coverage (accessed 7 October 2020).  
10 Government of the PRC. 2019. ‘Jing-jin-ji’: China’s Regional City Cluster Takes Shape. China Daily. 25 February.

3 
industry coordination capacity; and (iii) disseminating knowledge and lessons learned to health 
industry policy makers and regulators. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: health care industry in the BTH region 
strengthened (footnote 4). The TA will have the following outcome: policy coordination and 
development of the health care industry improved.11  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output  1:  Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei  health  care  industry  policies,  regulations  and 
guidelines, and markets assessed. To address the lack of comprehensive information and 
research on policy coordination; and gaps, needs, and opportunities in the health care industry in 
the BTH region, through the TA a comprehensive assessment will be carried out covering the 
following areas: (i) the industry including the current situation, key drivers of growth, market needs, 
institutional arrangements, and basic data on health industry development in relevant provinces 
and cities; (ii) government policies and regulations of the health care industry, including macro 
policies; implementation practices; industrial policies; and supporting national, provincial, and city 
policies of the health care industry; and (iii) coordinated development in the BTH region covering 
key industrial factors, policy factors, human resource talent and skills mix, financing, market 
entities, and scientific research institutions. 
 
10.  Output 2: Health industry coordination and innovation capacity strengthened. This 
output will focus on (i) developing a draft health care industry policy framework for coordination 
and innovation based on the assessments in output 1, (ii) generating evidence-based strategies 
and plans for the development of the health care industry in the BTH region, (iii) generating 
opportunities for consultations between health care industry stakeholders for better coordination 
and innovations nationally and globally, and (iv) identifying areas for potential future investment 
and/or development by public or private entities. Consultations on the policy framework will be 
conducted through a series of seminars and workshops held with all the relevant stakeholders:  
(i)  public  sector  (national,  regional,  provincial  officials,  and  pharmaceutical  regulators);                     
(ii) pharmaceutical and health care companies; (iii) academic research, professional associations, 
and development institutions; and (iv) purchasers. To further generate practical solutions and 
develop  ideas  for  improved  coordination  among  crucial  stakeholders,  ideation  workshops  
(sessions dedicated to generating new ideas) will be organized with industry and stakeholders, 
including information sharing with other provinces and representatives of economic zones that 
have successfully coordinated their industries, to absorb lessons learned and adapt potential 
strategies.  
 
11.  Output 3: Knowledge and lessons learned disseminated. This output will include the 
(i) preparation of a publication in Chinese and English on the draft policy framework, guidelines, 
lessons learned, and best practices for regional health care industry development in the context 
of the BTH region based on data from outputs 1 and 2; and (ii) dissemination of findings and 
lessons learned from the TA at the national, regional, and municipal levels during forums and 
meetings to facilitate adoption and implementation for provincial and national policy makers and 
regulators involved in the development of the health care industry. 
 
11 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $350,000, of which $300,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items 
are in Appendix 2. 
 
13.  The Hebei Provincial Finance Department will provide in-kind counterpart support in the 
form  of  office  accommodation  for  consultants,  venues  for  meetings,  counterpart  staff  and 
allowances, and miscellaneous administration expenses, including the printing and dissemination 
of TA reports and materials. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA. The Urban and Social Sectors Division of ADB’s East Asia 
Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants and monitor the quality of their work. 
The executing agency will be the Hebei Provincial Finance Department. The implementing agency 
will be the Hebei Institute of Fiscal Sciences and Policy. 
 
15.  The Hebei Institute of Fiscal Science and Policy will be responsible for providing guidance 
to the consultants engaged under the TA and, in partnership with the Hebei Provincial Finance 
Department, will coordinate with the relevant agencies and institutions involved under the TA. 
Reports produced under the TA will be made publicly available through existing knowledge 
sharing platforms and in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information Policy.12 Implementation 
arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements

16.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated procurement staff instructions.13 
To deliver the expected outputs, a health care industry consulting firm (national, 24 person-
months) and an individual consultant (international, 2 person-months) will be recruited. 
 
 
 
12 ADB. 2018. Access to Information Policy. Manila. 
13 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

5 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  Strengthening  Health  Care  Industry 
Development in Beijing–Tianjin–Hebei, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  BTH health care industry policies, regulations and guidelines, and markets assessed  
1.1 Engage consultants (Q1 2021) 
1.2 Initiate study design and data gathering of research study and evaluation (Q2 2021) 
1.3 Identify key stakeholders and critical institutions necessary for effective health care industry 
coordination (Q3 2021) 
1.4 Finalize the analysis of the research study and draft the research report (Q4 2021) 
1.5 Complete the publication of technical reports (Q2 2022) 
2.  Health industry coordination and innovation capacity strengthened 
2.1 Engage consultants (Q1 2021) 
2.2 Conduct a series of consultations with key stakeholders involved with coordinated development and 
innovations in the health care industry in BTH (Q3 2021) 
2.3 Conduct ideation and brainstorming workshops with stakeholders on how best to promote innovation 
and coordinate development in the health care industry in BTH (Q4 2021) 
2.4 Support the identification and development of effective institutional arrangements and partnerships 
for supporting innovations and coordination in the health care industry of BTH (Q2 2020) 
2.5 Complete the publication of technical reports (Q2 2022) 
3.  Knowledge and lessons learned disseminated 
3.1 Engage consultants (Q1 2021) 
3.2 Organize the inception, midterm, and final workshops to disseminate findings periodically and present 
the implementation status of the project (Q1 2021, Q4 2021, Q3 2022) 
3.3 Produce a publicly available knowledge product in the English and Chinese languages on the TA 
outputs and lessons learned (Q3 2022) 
3.4 Organize at least one dissemination workshop for policy makers, health care industry leaders, 
academic institutions, and other stakeholders on the lessons learned and outputs of the TA (Q3 2022)
